text: so a little background about us
Goldfinch bio was launched roughly two
years ago by third rock ventures we're
located in Cambridge Massachusetts
thirty full-time employees and growing
in my role and the companies that I work
in informatics and IT as part of the
computational research group
unfortunately our headcount hasn't grown
nearly as quickly as our AWS bill so
we're only four people three PhD
scientists and myself so a little bit
about the company so we our mission is
to lead a renaissance in the treatment
of kidney disease and kidney disease is
a global epidemic affecting 109 people
worldwide and staggering amount of money
is spent on it almost 20% of the u.s.
Medicare budget and unfortunately the
field really hasn't progressed in the
last 50 years since advent of dialysis
and transplant there really haven't any
been new haven't been any new treatments
for protein or kidney disease in that
time but there are a lot of companies
working in this space obviously we're
fairly new only two years old but using
recent technology advances and
personalized medicine we think that we
have a good chance to kind of make a
breakthrough here so the company's
product engine is driven by two core
components the kidney Genome Atlas which
will be the focus of the rest of the
talk and then the biology platform and
so we're focused on our personalized
medicine approach in that we're bringing
finding new targets to drug and also
finding patients to drug and so in doing
that we're taking two parallel analysis
paths downstream so we have our focused
analysis where we have a set of known
genes that are involved in kidney
function and we look at variants from
those genes and we test them in an
experimental assay and then we also have
an unbiased analysis where we're doing
things like a genome-wide Association
study identifying variants and then
again feel funnily into our biology
platform where we can use Hugin
organoids derive from patients with
kidney disease and what that's what's
shown there and microscopy image so the
kidney Genome Atlas is essentially a
large multi omics data set of patients
with kidney disease at the core of it is
whole genome sequencing data we started
in FSGS which is a rare form of kidney
disease and we sequenced over 2,000
patients there in addition to several
thousand
from the reference population which are
healthy patients without getting disease
in addition to that we also have some
RNA seek data where we are able to look
at transcriptomics from the same
patients that we have sequenced and then
also looking at biopsies
immunohistochemistry some proteomics
data and then we have longitudinal
medical records on all of these patients
going back as far as we can get them
from their medical providers and then
also looking at some newer sequencing
technologies like single-cell RNA seek
and our goal is pretty ambitious over
the next couple of years we're hoping a
sequence an additional 25,000 patients
moving into the diabetic nephropathy
space as well as sequencing 25,000
patients from the reference population
which are patients with diabetes but
without getting disease so so try to
file this multi omec data together
initially we're building a
genotype-phenotype correlation kind of
interface which is a web-based interface
written in angularjs using API is built
in the API gateway with lambda functions
or in Python and at the core that is a
query builder where any of our clinical
scientists and translational scientists
can go in and define a cohort of
patients of interest based on
demographic data lab results any of the
phenotypic data we're collecting and
then we present to them kind of
population level visualizations like
kaplan-meier plots box plots things like
that that show the overall population of
the cohort that they've defined and then
they're able to drill down into that
cohort to look at patient level details
and individual patients where we have
kind of a per patient page where they
can look at all the data we've collected
from any of those patients over time and
also predicted molecular diagnosis with
the hope that they can then start
looking at commonalities between these
patients and start digging into what are
the common genotypes related to that
phenotypes that we're looking at
supporting this interface is a large
amount of relational data so we're using
Amazon Arora and a whole suite of
relational databases that we built so
with any large scale sequencing project
we have multiple collaborators we have
multiple sequencing CRO s
and so just keeping track of the
logistics of all that data is pretty
challenging and so we have databases and
API is to help us with all of this you
know samples are constantly failing we
have multiple batches going on at the
same time across different providers and
a lot of metadata associate
with that that we keep track of and then
we also have a lot of QC metrics so
before samples get sequenced with
library prep they get tested to make
sure the DNA is good quality and then
during the pipeline data analysis as
well we collect a lot of metrics there
that we dump back into our relational
databases and then we have longitudinal
medical records so clinical data and
medication data over time and that comes
in a variety of formats every data
delivery we get from every collaborator
is a different format and the data needs
a lot of cleaning kind of massaging
before we can load it in or normalize
schema then we also have quite a bit of
reference data there's leather multi
omec data there's public gos data gene
expression data and proteomics data and
then annotations as well from public
databases gene variant annotations we
use a nomad database from Dana
MacArthur's lab at the broad and then in
the first half of next year we're hoping
to add a clinical data warehouse to this
as well as we begin our first clinical
trial where we're enrolling patients
from the KGA that we already have a lot
of data on and we'll hopefully be able
to add those data points as well to what
we already know about them all of the
state is versioned over time because
it's really important that all of our
results are reproducible so all the
schema has baked into it kind of
versioning tables and immutable records
so we're running a standard DNA
sequenced we decided very early on that
we needed to start with a commercial
vendor to do the orchestration of the
sequence analysis because we thought we
just didn't have the resources of the
bandwidth of at the very limited staff
to be able to do that ourselves so we
partnered with a commercial organization
that could do the orchestration and we
decided we wanted to use a gatk workflow
out of the Broad Institute as kind of
the gold standard in the space and so we
we licensed sentian which is a
commercial implementation of gatk that
comes with support which was very
appealing to us and we worked with that
commercial vendor to implement the gatk
workflow or the Santee on workflow on
AWS for us and we ran into a lot of
issues with that approach
I was very buggy didn't really deliver
as promised and so we realized pretty
quickly that this wasn't a good
scaleable solution for us long term so
now we're in the process of
re-engineering that natively on batch
we've been playing with Cromwell out of
the road institute as a work for
orchestration engine and the folks at a
treehouse did a nice job adding support
to that with batch and then all of our
data is stored on s3 we're pretty
aggressive about archiving that to
Glacier and then we are doing to your
question earlier we are doing joint
calling on a quarterly basis across the
entire data set and so the way that we
do that is we split the genome up into
roughly a thousand segments and then for
each of our six thousand samples we push
so we push roughly six million files on
that data set to s 3 and then we
orchestrate this on batch is basically
just a big MapReduce problem where we
map over all the segments we apply the
joint calling algorithm so we get
roughly a thousand VCS as a result and
we merge those together and then we do
varying quality score recalibration
where it's essentially MapReduce and the
other dimension where we're splitting on
samples instead of genomic regions so we
get our final output there which and all
of this data lives on s3 and then we
also have a QC pipeline as well that
gets orchestrated as part of that as
well so as I mentioned with our
commercial solution we had a lot of
problems with scalability they also have
a data warehousing component which was
really a data silo and as we're building
out this interface and this multi-omics
data set that just really wasn't a good
scalable solution for us and so we're in
the process now of re-architecting that
as a native data like basically an s3 so
we'll take our view PSR data and we'll
load that onto an EMR cluster right now
I'm pushing that in HDFS and then using
the atom library as we convert the VCF
to park' and that enables us to use AWS
glue to create a external table in the
meta store and then use Athena to query
that data and once we're able to write
basic sequel queries against it we can
start doing some basic filtering and
looking at variants and genes that are
significantly enriched in the kidney
disease population versus a reference
population and we also use a nomad
database to select for variants that are
significantly more rare compared to the
reference population we've also been
using Amazon quick site for basic
dashboards about the project we have so
many different cohorts and so many
different
batches of data being sequence at the
same time we needed some easy visuals to
kind of understand what the status of
each of those batches are and each of
the different cohorts are and then we're
hoping to be able to deliver to our
collaboratives well an interface where
as they're recontacting patients they
can actually update that in real time
through the web interface and we'll have
additional dashboards related to that so
we have a very patient centric kind of
view of the data set that we're building
as well as the view of growth over time
of the data we're also using EMR quite a
bit for our downstream analyses as I
mentioned what the focus and unbiased
analysis and so we're using hail from
the Broad Institute as our genomic
framework that we're doing our analysis
on which runs on SPARC and so we're able
to bootstrap any more cluster with all
of that installed we also adapted the VP
libraries from the Broad Institute to be
able to run on Amazon for variant
annotation which has been really helpful
and so they were able to use SPARC and a
reasonably large cluster to do our
genome-wide Association studies we've
also been looking at eqtl analysis and
then these downstream analyses kind of
funneled towards our ability to identify
new targets as we layer on additional
information public research and
literature and things like that
that we add on as well and then with the
introduction of urinary proteomics we
were able to also look for biomarkers
we've also been doing network analysis
in the data set and so shown on the left
is just a kaplan-meier plot of
predicting kidney survival over time but
we're also been playing with loading the
whole network of the whole human genome
into Amazon Neptune which is a graph
database so that we can start asking
questions like what are the what's the
neighborhood around a gene of interest
what are the edge weights between
different genes that we might be
interested in and hopefully deliver
something like this animation I have up
here which is a force directed graph
written in d3 where we could present
that to a user where they can look at
the topology of the graph in a region of
interest and start understanding kind of
what are the genes or the neighbors
around genes that are interesting and
then we can use that to I expand our
focused analysis so that we have a
larger set of genes to start with that
we're interested in so in summary we've
been able to do a lot with a really
small team and a fairly short amount of
time thanks in large part to AWS and the
platform that they offer and hopefully
relatively soon we'll be able to bring
new medicines to this underserved
population
[Applause]
